## ðŸ” Authentication Endpoints

Manage user authentication, registration, login, logout, and token refresh.

### ðŸ“‹ Available Endpoints

- **Sign Up**: Register a new user account
- **Login**: Authenticate and get access/refresh tokens
- **Logout**: End current session
- **Refresh Token**: Get new access token using refresh token

**Note**: For session management endpoints (list sessions, delete sessions, etc.), see the "ðŸ“± User Sessions" section.

item.name: ðŸ“ Sign Up
item.description:
## ðŸ“ Register New User

Register a new user account in the system.

### ðŸ“¥ Request Body

```json
{
  "email": "user@example.com",
  "password": "Password123",
  "fullName": "John Doe",
  "role": "customer"
}
```

### âœ… Success Response (201 Created)

```json
{
  "message": "User registered successfully",
  "user": {
    "id": "uuid",
    "email": "user@example.com"
  },
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "expires_in": 900,
  "refresh_expires_in": 604800
}
```

**Note**: Authentication tokens are sent as HttpOnly cookies (`access_token` and `refresh_token`) for security.

**Response Fields:**
- `message`: Confirmation message
- `user`: Newly created user information (id, email)
- `token_type`: Type of token (always "Bearer")
- `expires_in`: Access token expiration time in seconds (900 = 15 minutes)
- `refresh_expires_in`: Refresh token expiration time in seconds (604800 = 7 days)

**HTTP Headers:**
- `Location`: URI of the created resource (e.g., `/api/user/me`)

**HTTP Status Code**: `201 Created` - Sign up creates a new user resource, so it returns 201 Created.

### ðŸ”„ Auto-Actions

- âœ… Automatically extracts `access_token` from cookies and saves to environment
- âœ… Automatically extracts `refresh_token` from cookies and saves to environment
- âœ… Automatically saves `user_id` to environment
- âœ… Automatically saves `user_email` to environment

item.name: ðŸ”‘ Login
item.description:
## ðŸ”‘ User Login

Authenticate user and receive access/refresh tokens.

### ðŸ“¥ Request Body

```json
{
  "email": "{{user_email}}",
  "password": "{{user_password}}"
}
```

### âœ… Success Response (200 OK)

```json
{
  "user": {
    "id": "uuid",
    "email": "user@example.com"
  },
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "expires_in": 900,
  "refresh_expires_in": 604800
}
```

**Note**: Authentication tokens are sent as HttpOnly cookies (`access_token` and `refresh_token`) for security.

**Response Fields:**
- `user`: User information (id, email)
- `token_type`: Type of token (always "Bearer")
- `expires_in`: Access token expiration time in seconds (900 = 15 minutes)
- `refresh_expires_in`: Refresh token expiration time in seconds (604800 = 7 days)

**HTTP Status Code**: `200 OK` - Login is an authentication operation, not a resource creation, so it returns 200 OK instead of 201 Created.

### âš ï¸ Error Responses

- **401 Unauthorized**: Invalid credentials
- **429 Too Many Requests**: Too many login attempts

### ðŸ”„ Auto-Actions

- âœ… Automatically extracts `access_token` from cookies and saves to environment
- âœ… Automatically extracts `refresh_token` from cookies and saves to environment
- âœ… Automatically saves `user_id` to environment
- âœ… Automatically saves `user_email` to environment

### ðŸ’¡ Usage

Use the environment variables `{{user_email}}` and `{{user_password}}` for quick login.

item.name: ðŸ”„ Refresh Token
item.description:
## ðŸ”„ Refresh Access Token

Get a new access token using a valid refresh token.

### ðŸ“¥ Request Body

```json
{
  "refreshToken": "{{refresh_token}}"
}
```

**Note**: The refresh token can also be sent via cookie `refresh_token`. The endpoint accepts both.

### âœ… Success Response (200 OK)

```json
{
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "expires_in": 900,
  "refresh_expires_in": 604800
}
```

**Note**: New authentication tokens are sent as HttpOnly cookies (`access_token` and `refresh_token`).

**Response Fields:**
- `token_type`: Type of token (always "Bearer")
- `expires_in`: New access token expiration time in seconds (900 = 15 minutes)
- `refresh_expires_in`: Refresh token expiration time in seconds (604800 = 7 days)

### ðŸ”„ Auto-Actions

- âœ… Automatically extracts `access_token` from cookies and updates environment
- âœ… Automatically extracts `refresh_token` from cookies and updates environment

item.name: Logout
item.description:
## ðŸšª User Logout

End the current session and invalidate the access token.

### ðŸ”’ Authentication

Requires valid Bearer token in Authorization header.

### âœ… Success Response (200 OK)

```json
{
  "message": "Successfully logged out"
}
```

**Note**: Authentication cookies (`access_token` and `refresh_token`) are cleared.

**HTTP Status Code**: `200 OK` - Logout is a state-changing operation that returns a confirmation message.

request.description: Logout from the current session. Invalidates the current access token and clears authentication cookies.

## ðŸ“± User Session Management

- **Update Session Last Used**: Update session last used timestamp

item.name: ðŸ‘¤ Get My Profile
item.description:
## ðŸ‘¤ Get Current User Profile

Get the complete profile information of the currently authenticated user.

### ðŸ”’ Authentication

Requires valid Bearer token in Authorization header.

### âœ… Success Response (200 OK)

```json
{
  "id": "user-uuid",
  "email": "user@example.com",
  "fullName": "John Doe",
  "role": {
    "id": 1,
    "name": "customer"
  },
  "isActive": true,
  "isApproved": true,
  "isOnline": false,
  "createdAt": "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z",
  "lastLogin": "2024-01-08T20:00:00.000Z",
  "lastActivityAt": "2024-01-08T21:00:00.000Z",
  "profile": {
    "id": "profile-uuid",
    "profileType": "customer",
    "profileId": null,
    "metadata": {},
    "createdAt": "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z",
    "updatedAt": "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z"
  }
}
```

**Response Fields:**
- `id`: User unique identifier
- `email`: User email address
- `fullName`: User full name
- `role`: User role information (id, name)
- `isActive`: Whether the user account is active
- `isApproved`: Whether the user account is approved
- `isOnline`: Whether the user is currently online
- `createdAt`: Account creation timestamp
- `lastLogin`: Last login timestamp (optional)
- `lastActivityAt`: Last activity timestamp (optional)
- `profile`: User profile information (optional, null if no profile exists)

### âš ï¸ Error Responses

- **401 Unauthorized**: Invalid or expired token
- **404 Not Found**: User not found or inactive

**Note**: This is the endpoint for getting user profile information.

item.name: ðŸ” Roles & Permissions
item.description:
## ðŸ” Roles & Permissions Management

Complete RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) system for managing roles, permissions, and permission groups.

### ðŸ“‹ Available Endpoints

#### Roles
- **Get All Roles**: List all roles
- **Get Role by ID**: Get role details
- **Update Role**: Update role and permission groups

**Note**: Roles are created via database seeds (`npm run seed:roles`), not through API endpoints. This ensures consistency with SystemRole enum values. Roles cannot be deleted as they are defined in the SystemRole enum and are essential for the system's RBAC architecture.

#### Permissions
- **Get All Permissions**: List all permissions
- **Get Permission by ID**: Get permission details
- **Update Permission**: Update permission

**Note**: Permissions are created via database seeds (`npm run seed:permissions`), not through API endpoints. This ensures consistency with Permission enum values. Permissions cannot be deleted as they are defined in the Permission enum and are essential for the system's RBAC architecture.

#### Permission Groups
- **Get All Permission Groups**: List all permission groups
- **Get Permission Group by ID**: Get group details
- **Update Permission Group**: Update group and permissions

**Note**: Permission groups are created via database seeds (`npm run seed:groups`), not through API endpoints. This ensures consistency with the system configuration. Permission groups cannot be deleted as they are essential for the system's RBAC architecture.

### ðŸ‘¤ User Role Assignment

User roles are assigned directly through the User entity (one role per user). Role assignment is handled through user management endpoints, not through separate user-role endpoints.

### ðŸ”’ Authentication

All endpoints require:
- Valid Bearer token in Authorization header
- Role: `admin`
- Permission: `manage_users`
